ygData.subject: RE: [EQ_women] Lifespan of EQ
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi everyone, I ve been playing since Christmas 1999..a little over a year...and my Paladin just hit Level 50. It was a very exciting moment for me. I am still
ygData.messageBody:
Hi everyone,

I've been playing since Christmas 1999..a little over
a year...and my Paladin just hit Level 50. It was a
very exciting moment for me. I am still to this day
amazed at the lands I'm just beginning to explore and
the creatures that I'm just now "old" enough to kill.
I never have a difficult time finding a group nor does
my level 50 Ranger fiancee. The game is really a lot
about networking. Very much like the real world. At
higher levels you will go into a zone and say "Hello
Karnors Castle" (for example) and half the castle will
holler back "Hello Lily!". I never thought I would
have so many friends and acquaintances. To me that's
what EQ is about. The people I've met and the good
times I've had with them. I don't see EQ ending for me
because it's not only a game. These folks are my
friends. Just to let you know I am able to balance EQ
and RL. I have a full time job and a family that lives
close by and I even clean my house! :-) I'm 38 years
old and I've found something that keeps me young at
heart. EQ.

Lilyana
Level 50 Paladin
Karana
--- P MacKinnon <tash@...> wrote:
> Hello all
>
> Short intro - I'm a 40 something woman (natch)
> sequestered in the Frozen North aka Ontario, and I
> just started playing EQ a few weeks ago. Life as I
> knew it is over; My time is now divided into EQ,
> and all that other stuff I have to take care of
> before I get back to EQ. ^_^ This will wear off
> as the snow melts I hope, but now I understand why
> they call it "Evercrack."
>
> I'm so new I squeak (just hit 5th level with my
> druid and monk last night), but one of the main
> attractions to me right now is exploration. (I
> guess I'm still in the gee whiz stage ^_^) I don't
> know how the game will appear to me once I run out
> of places to explore. I'm going to try trades as
> well, and that will add another dimension, but I
> think at some point Verant may have to offer
> something new to keep the longer term players
> involved. Expansion packs will fill the need for
> now, but eventually an overhaul of the graphics and
> terrain of the original world should be considered.
> That might refresh things for people a bit.
>
> All this is, of course, in my extremely humble,
> low-level, can't-even-run-my-scared
> little-newbie-past-West Commons opinion. ^_^ Who
> know what I'll be thinking when I'm a veteran.
>
> cheers!
>
> Patti
> Wuvian - level 5 (!) (count 'em ==> 5 <== ) Druid,
> Saryn
>
> p.s. At what point do your non-eq women friends
> start rebelling now that conversations invariably
> turn to the interesting and new way you found to die
> last night?
>
> ---
>
> I have been playing EQ since the day it came out.
>
> Still addicted. hehehe.
>
> Got Diablo2 and that swayed me a little but not for
> long
>
> Rosalind
> Soril level 33 Druid Tunare server
>
> Elizabeth Adams wrote:
>
> > I just wondered how long the shelf life of EQ is?
> I have played since
> > 24 August 2000, and I tend to feel that I could
> carry on playing for
> > around a year, so long as I could get groups. EQ
> does not strike me
> > as a game I could easily play casually though, so
> I probably wouldn't
> > play fewer hours per week over a longer period.
> >
> > I think the decisive factor would be in-game; it's
> a miserable
> > occupation if you can't play as part of a group,
> so if it comes to
> > the point where my ranger cannot get into groups,
> it will probably be
> > time to move on. I suppose I might try another
> class, but I am not
> > that interested in doing so.
> >
> > Liz xx
> >
> > aka Gyngermynx, ranger of the 32nd season,
> Quellious
>
>
>

> ATTACHMENT part 2 application/ms-tnef
